title: If resistance R1 and R2 is connected in parallel, what is the resultant resistance? - Quora

response.answer_text: Two ways: R = (R1 x R2) / (R1 + R2)R = 1 / (1/R1 + 1/R2) On a calculator: input R1, press 1/x, then press +, input R2, press 1/x, press =, then 1/x. If you have more resistors of various values in parallel, just continue inputting their values and pressing 1/x after each, and press = when you got all of them, and then 1/x. Very simple, and fairly fast.
If resistance R1 and R2 is connected in parallel, what is the resultant resistance? Someone isn't paying attention in class. For parallel: 1/Rt = 1/R1 + 1/R2 + ……. 1/Rn
in parallel connection, you are simply adding more conductors to the circuit, therefore, you expect the net resistance to go down. which is given by fractioning the product of the two by their sum.
